Thinking back on this course, I am astounded by how much I learned and how much more confident I feel in my research and in the quantitative side of what I study. In terms of strengths, the professor and TFs provided us with so many resources to succeed (course notes, problem sets, multiple sections each week, extra practice problems and practice exams, etc. etc.). The topics were organized thoughtfully and built well on one another. The examples were fun and engaging, as was class. Can't think of any improvements.

I thought it was helpful to have weekly problem sets, but I would have benefited more from them if the questions represented a range of difficulty levels. I felt that most of the problems were difficult to the point that it was difficult to connect them to the material we covered in lecture. Alternatively, adding optional drills to the curriculum might solve this problem.

- Professor Chang was great and very engaging
- HWs were a significant time commitment but only a small part of the grade
Materials are so good.
Learned a lot about theory and also application.
No weaknesses, very good.
The course combines theory and applications and lets us use R to do problems. I learned a lot from the course.

Good crash course, worth the time

Absolutely. As a graduate student, this course is already highly regarded within my department, and I will certainly continue to pass on the recommendation. Applied science students will encounter probability (and all of the course concepts) time and time again, and this class helps you ground yourself in a real understanding that I didn't realize could even exist... As someone coming from a weaker quantitative background, and still able to survive in this class, I'd recommend this class to people of all levels as an effort worth undertaking.
Yes, I found this course difficult but beneficial to my education.

I would highly recommend this course to any student who wants to learn the basics as well as applications of Bayesian analysis.
